definition: The most common form of vasculitis, characterized by neutrophil-mediated inflammation and damage to small vessel walls (post-capillary venules). Often used synonymously with 'Cutaneous Small Vessel Vasculitis'.
clinical: Presents as palpable purpura, typically in dependent areas (lower legs). Lesions may progress to vesicles, bullae, nodules, or ulcers. If slightly larger vessels in the mid-reticular dermis are involved, can present with fixed livedo.
pathogenesis: Immune complex deposition in vessel walls leading to complement activation, neutrophil attraction, enzyme release, and vessel wall damage. Causes include idiopathic (most common), medications, infections, and malignancy.
macroscopic: Red-purple palpable papules (palpable purpura). Can have hemorrhagic vesicles or central necrosis.
microscopic: Neutrophils within the vessel wall and perivascular zone. Fibrinoid necrosis (fibrin in vessel wall). Leukocytoclasia (nuclear dust/fragmented neutrophil nuclei). Extravasated erythrocytes. Secondary thrombi may be present.
ancillary_studies: Direct Immunofluorescence (DIF): Best on lesions <24 hours old. Shows C3 and IgM in vessel walls (early), C3 and fibrinogen (late).
differential_diagnosis: Henoch-Schönlein Purpura (IgA dominant), Urticarial Vasculitis, Septic Vasculitis, Thrombotic Vasculopathy.
prognosis_and_prediction: Depends on underlying cause and systemic involvement.

related_figures.legend: Schema illustrating correlation between vessel depth/size and clinical presentation (palpable purpura vs. livedo). (Time: 561s)
High power showing neutrophils around a vessel and fibrin deposition within the vessel wall. (Time: 740s)
Demonstrates fibrin in vessel walls, neutrophils, leukocytoclasia, and secondary thrombus formation. (Time: 819s)
Direct Immunofluorescence (DIF) showing immunoreactant deposition in vessel walls. (Time: 867s)

definition: A specific subtype of leukocytoclastic vasculitis characterized by IgA immune complex deposition.
clinical: Palpable purpura, often in children. Can have systemic involvement including renal (hematuria/proteinuria) and gastrointestinal tract (pain).
macroscopic: Palpable purpura, typically on buttocks and lower extremities.
microscopic: Identical to leukocytoclastic vasculitis: neutrophils, nuclear dust, fibrinoid necrosis, and extravasated erythrocytes.
ancillary_studies: Direct Immunofluorescence (DIF): Shows IgA deposition in vessel walls (definitive feature).
differential_diagnosis: Acute Hemorrhagic Edema of Infancy (IgA negative), other forms of LCV.
prognosis_and_prediction: Generally self-limited; prognosis depends on renal involvement.

related_figures.legend: Direct Immunofluorescence showing IgA deposition in blood vessel walls. (Time: 928s)

definition: A form of leukocytoclastic vasculitis affecting infants.
clinical: Occurs in children/infants. Large, targetoid, plaque-like lesions often described as having a 'Cockade' (knot of ribbons) pattern or rosette shape.
macroscopic: Edematous, hemorrhagic plaques and targetoid lesions.
ancillary_studies: Direct Immunofluorescence (DIF): Negative for IgA (distinguishes from HSP).

related_figures.legend: Clinical presentation showing targetoid, 'cockade' pattern lesions. (Time: 1072s)

definition: Vasculitis caused by the deposition of cryoglobulins (proteins that precipitate below 37°C) in vessel walls.
pathogenesis: Frequently associated with Hepatitis C infection. Immune complexes containing cryoglobulins deposit in vessels.
microscopic: Leukocytoclastic vasculitis. May show intraluminal cryoglobulin precipitates (hyaline thrombi).
ancillary_studies: Serology for cryoglobulins and Hepatitis C.
prognosis_and_prediction: Depends on management of underlying Hepatitis C or lymphoproliferative disorder.

related_figures.legend: Text slide description. (Time: 1112s)

definition: A chronic, localized form of small vessel vasculitis typically affecting the face.
clinical: Red-brown papules, plaques, or nodules primarily on the face. Can be single or multiple.
microscopic: Mixed dermal infiltrate containing neutrophils, eosinophils, lymphocytes, and histiocytes. Neutrophils cluster around vessels with mild leukocytoclasia. A distinctive 'Grenz zone' is typically spared. Older lesions show concentric 'onion-skin' fibrosis around vessels.
differential_diagnosis: Sarcoidosis, Tuberculosis, Tumid Lupus, Lymphoma, Rosacea.

related_figures.legend: Clinical presentation of red-brown plaques on the face. (Time: 1252s)
Mixed infiltrate with eosinophils, histiocytes, and neutrophils. (Time: 1375s)
Later lesion showing concentric fibrosis around blood vessels. (Time: 1383s)

definition: A rare, chronic fibrosing leukocytoclastic vasculitis.
clinical: Erythematous to purple/brown plaques, nodules, or indurated plaques, typically on extensor surfaces (elbows, knees, hands). Associated with arthralgias and paraproteins (IgA gammopathy).
microscopic: Leukocytoclastic vasculitis associated with granulation tissue and significant fibrosis. Older lesions show fibrosis in a storiform pattern. Cholesterol clefts may be seen.
differential_diagnosis: Granuloma Faciale (usually on face), Dermatofibroma (storiform pattern), Kaposi Sarcoma.

related_figures.legend: Clinical presentation of a plaque on the elbow. (Time: 1419s)
Low power showing storiform fibrosis and inflammation. (Time: 1462s)
Neutrophils and eosinophils associated with fibrosis. (Time: 1480s)

definition: A clinicopathologic entity characterized by urticarial lesions that show histologic features of vasculitis.
clinical: Urticarial papules or plaques that persist >24 hours, are painful/burning rather than itchy, and resolve with residual purpura or hyperpigmentation. May be associated with hypocomplementemia and SLE.
microscopic: Features of leukocytoclastic vasculitis (neutrophils, fibrin, nuclear dust) but often with more prominent dermal edema than classic LCV.
prognosis_and_prediction: Hypocomplementemic form is associated with systemic disease (SLE, COPD).

related_figures.legend: Histologic example showing LCV features with edema. (Time: 1564s)

definition: A necrotizing vasculitis affecting small to medium-sized muscular arteries.
clinical: Subcutaneous nodules, ulcers, livedo reticularis. Can be purely cutaneous or systemic. Systemic PAN is a serious disease.
pathogenesis: Immune mediated. Associated with Hepatitis B surface antigen, cryoglobulinemia.
microscopic: Involves medium-sized muscular arteries in the deep dermis or subcutis. Neutrophilic infiltrate (early) becoming mixed/mononuclear (late). Fibrinoid necrosis of the vessel wall. Involvement is often segmental. Requires deep incisional biopsy.
ancillary_studies: Hepatitis B serologies. ANCA is typically negative.
differential_diagnosis: Other medium vessel vasculitides, nodular vasculitis.
prognosis_and_prediction: Systemic PAN has high morbidity; Cutaneous PAN is chronic but benign.

related_figures.legend: Clinical presentation showing livedo pattern and ulceration. (Time: 1679s)
Low power showing deep involvement in subcutaneous tissue. (Time: 1741s)
Medium-sized vessel with mural neutrophils and fibrin. (Time: 1752s)

definition: A localized inflammatory condition resulting from abnormal response to cold, classified as a lymphocytic vasculitis.
clinical: Erythematous to blue-violet macules, papules, or nodules on acral sites (distal digits, toes) after cold exposure. May blister or ulcerate.
microscopic: Papillary dermal edema. Superficial and deep lymphocytic infiltrate. Lymphocytic vasculitis features: endothelial swelling, fibrin in walls (sometimes), and extravasated erythrocytes.
prognosis_and_prediction: Self-limiting but recurrent with cold exposure.

related_figures.legend: Low power showing papillary dermal edema and superficial/deep infiltrate. (Time: 1878s)
Extravasated erythrocytes and lymphocytic inflammation. (Time: 1891s)

definition: A spectrum of inflammatory dermatoses exhibiting features of both interface dermatitis and lymphocytic vasculitis.
clinical: PLEVA (Acute): Crops of crusting, hemorrhagic papules that may scar. PLC (Chronic): Scaly red-brown papules resolving with hypopigmentation.
macroscopic: Red-brown papules with central scale or crust.
microscopic: Wedge-shaped dermal infiltrate. Band-like lymphocytic interface dermatitis with necrotic keratinocytes. Lymphocytic vasculitis (endothelial swelling, extravasated erythrocytes). Broad parakeratosis.
differential_diagnosis: Lymphomatoid Papulosis (LyP), Guttate Psoriasis, Lichen Planus.
prognosis_and_prediction: Variable course; rare progression to cutaneous lymphoma reported.

related_figures.legend: Clinical presentation of red-brown papules with central crust. (Time: 1995s)
Low power showing band-like infiltrate and wedge shape. (Time: 2055s)
Extravasated erythrocytes and necrotic keratinocytes. (Time: 2067s)

definition: An ANCA-associated small-to-medium vessel vasculitis characterized by granulomatous inflammation, formerly known as Wegener Granulomatosis.
clinical: Involves upper/lower respiratory tract and kidneys. Cutaneous lesions include palpable purpura, subcutaneous nodules, and large ulcers (pyoderma gangrenosum-like).
microscopic: Paradoxically, cutaneous lesions most commonly show leukocytoclastic vasculitis (LCV) without granulomas. Granulomatous vasculitis is rare in skin biopsies despite the disease name.

related_figures.legend: Histology showing prominent neutrophilic vasculitis (LCV pattern). (Time: 2275s)

definition: An ANCA-associated vasculitis characterized by asthma, eosinophilia, and granulomatous inflammation, formerly known as Churg-Strauss Syndrome.
clinical: Asthma, allergic rhinitis, peripheral eosinophilia. Skin lesions: Palpable purpura, nodules.
microscopic: Vasculitis of small arteries or veins. Mixed infiltrate with prominent eosinophils. Extravascular necrotizing granulomas (palisading granulomas) are seen in ~50% of cutaneous biopsies.

related_figures.legend: Extravascular necrotizing granuloma with eosinophils. (Time: 2354s)

definition: Granulomatous vasculitis involving medium to large elastic arteries.
clinical: Headache, jaw claudication, visual disturbance (blindness risk). Scalp tenderness, necrosis, or ulceration.
microscopic: Involves large arteries (temporal). Granulomatous inflammation with multinucleated giant cells, lymphocytes, and histiocytes disrupting the internal elastic lamina. Segmental involvement (skip lesions).
ancillary_studies: Elastic stains (Verhoeff-Van Gieson) to demonstrate disruption of internal elastic lamina.
prognosis_and_prediction: Requires prompt steroids to prevent blindness.

related_figures.legend: Large vessel with mural inflammation and giant cells. (Time: 2420s)

definition: Vascular occlusive disease caused by intraluminal thrombi rather than primary vessel wall inflammation.
clinical: Retiform (angulated) purpura, necrosis, ulcers, livedo reticularis.
pathogenesis: Hypercoagulable states (Factor V Leiden, Protein C/S deficiency, Lupus anticoagulant), Cryoglobulinemia, Sepsis, Calciphylaxis.
microscopic: Fibrin thrombi within the lumen of venules or arterioles. Bland thrombi (minimal inflammation), though secondary inflammation can occur later. Ischemic necrosis of overlying skin.

related_figures.legend: Multiple superficial vessels occluded by fibrin thrombi with minimal inflammation. (Time: 2510s)

definition: A specific form of chronic thrombotic vasculopathy affecting the lower extremities.
clinical: Purpuric papules/plaques evolving into painful ulcers, healing with porcelain-white atrophic scars (atrophie blanche). Associated with livedo reticularis.
pathogenesis: Prothrombotic/occlusive states (Lupus anticoagulant, Protein C/S deficiency, Factor V Leiden).
macroscopic: White angular scars with peripheral telangiectasia/pigmentation.
microscopic: Fibrin thrombi within the lumen AND thickened vessel walls ('outline' appearance). Hyalinized vessel walls. Minimal inflammation.
ancillary_studies: PAS stain: Positive (highlights thickened vessel walls).

related_figures.legend: Clinical appearance of porcelain white scars (Atrophie Blanche). (Time: 2598s)
Vessels with thickened, hyalinized walls ('outline' appearance) and fibrin thrombi. (Time: 2625s)
